article.title: Authentication Basics
article.para: JPA Security uses an implementation of the net.sf.jpasecurity.authentication.AuthenticationProvider interface to be aware of the currently authenticated user and/or it's roles at runtime.

section.title: Default-Configuration for Authentication
section.para: By default JPA Security will try to auto-detect your authentication provider. The detection follows the following rules (The first matching rule is taken):

listitem.para: When acegi-security is in the classpath, the AcegiAuthenticationProvider is used.
When spring-security is in the classpath, the SpringAuthenticationProvider is used.
When java:comp/EJBContext is available in the JNDI-context, the EJBAuthenticationProvider is used.

section.title: Customizing Authentication
section.para: When the described auto-detection strategy does not work for you, you may specify any implementation of the net.sf.jpasecurity.security.AuthenticationProvider interface as value of the persistence-property net.sf.jpasecurity.security.authentication.provider in your persistence.xml. You may use any of the above described authentication providers or implement your own.
